title: BBC News
text:
Downs for People

Bristol council is taking legal advice to determine whether people visiting Bristol Zoo Gardens can continue to park on The Downs amid a dispute over the zoo’s right to use the land.

The zoo was expected to stop letting customers park on the 1.34ha site next to Ladies Mile when official permission for overflow parking on that part of Clifton Down expires at the end of the year.

But opponents of the zoo’s use of the land claim zoo bosses have told them they can keep letting visitors park there without specific planning permission.

Bristol City Council said it is taking legal advice on the matter.

The zoo promised in 2017 it would not submit another application for temporary planning permission for car parking when the current permission expires on December 31.

It has repeated assurance several times this year. But lobby group Downs for People told the group which manages The Downs last week that: “Dr Justin Morris, the current chief executive, has explained to us that this assurance did not mean that parking would end.

“The zoo considers it can use the site for parking for up to 28 days a year without specific permission,” they said in a public forum statement to the Downs Committee on September 23.

The zoo did not confirm the claim when asked by the Local Democracy Reporting Service.

Nor did it respond to questions over the lobby group’s further suggestion the zoo’s claimed right to use the land for up to 28 days without specific permission was “refuted in 1990 with the support of the city council’s legal advisors”.

A council spokesman said its officers were unable to find any record of such a decision.

“The council is taking legal advice regarding this situation,” he said.
